content:
That's great to hear that the Champion 20 has helped you improve your playing and tone! It's always exciting to explore new sounds and techniques, and it's even more fulfilling when you feel like you're making progress.

It's completely normal to focus on one instrument or style for a while, and it's awesome that you're not feeling guilty about setting the acoustic guitar aside for now. Sometimes, taking a break from an instrument can help you come back to it with fresh ears and a new perspective.

Playing acoustic versions of your electric guitar songs can be a great way to challenge yourself and explore different arrangements. You might be surprised at how a song can take on a new life when played on a different instrument. Who knows, you might even discover a new favorite way to play a particular song!

When you do decide to pick up the acoustic guitar again, you might find that your electric guitar playing has influenced your acoustic playing, and vice versa. You might bring some of the techniques or ideas you've developed on electric guitar to your acoustic playing, which can be a great way to breathe new life into your music.

Remember, the most important thing is to keep playing, experimenting, and having fun. Enjoy the process of learning and growing as a musician, and don't worry too much about which instrument you're playing at any given time.
